abstract.p: In this paper a novel high-quality reconstruction scheme is presented. Although our method is mainly proposed to reconstruct volumetric data sampled on an optimal Body-Centered Cubic (BCC) grid, it can be easily adapted to the conventional regular rectilinear grid as well. The reconstruction process is decomposed into two steps. The first step, which is considered to be a preprocessing, is a discrete Gaussian deconvolution performed only once in the frequency domain. Afterwards, the second step is a spatial-domain convolution with a truncated Gaussian kernel, which is used to interpolate arbitrary samples for ray casting. Since the preprocessing is actually a discrete prefiltering, we call our technique Prefiltered Gaussian Reconstruction (PGR). It is shown that the impulse response of PGR well approximates the ideal reconstruction kernel. Therefore the quality of PGR is much higher than that of previous reconstruction techniques proposed for optimally sampled data, which are based on linear and cubic box splines adapted to the BCC grid (see Figure 1). Concerning the performance, PGR is slower than linear box-spline reconstruction but significantly faster than cubic box-spline reconstruction.

div.head: INTRODUCTION
div.p: Generally volume data is supposed to be a discrete representation of an underlying continuous phenomenon. The accuracy of this discrete representation is strongly influenced by that, where and how frequently the samples are taken from the original function (or signal). From a signal-processing point of view, the original continuous signal can be perfectly reconstructed from the samples, if it is band-limited and the sampling frequency is above the Nyquist limit [21].

Samples are usually defined on a rectilinear grid, which has several practical advantages. For instance, samples are stored in 3D arrays, therefore they can be easily addressed. Furthermore, for many volume-processing or rendering algorithms it is important to rapidly access the neighboring voxels of a certain voxel. Convolution-based filtering or interpolation, for example, can be efficiently implemented on a rectilinear grid.

Nevertheless, it is well known that a rectilinear grid is not optimal, even if the cells are congruent cubes resulting in a Cartesian Cubic (CC) grid [22]. An optimal grid is derived from the classical sphere-packing problem [5,23]. Assume that the original signal has a spherical spectrum (there are no preferred directions). The spectrum of the sampled signal contains the replicas of the primary spectrum, centered at the points of the dual (or reciprocal) of the sampling grid [21]. The original signal can be reconstructed if there is no overlapping between the replicas. On the other hand, the sparsest sampling in the spatial domain corresponds to the tightest arrangement of spheres in the frequency domain. In this sense, an optimal sphere packing grid is the Face-Centered Cubic (FCC) grid, therefore its dual, which is the Body-Centered Cubic (BCC) grid, is an optimal sampling pattern [26]. Although the BCC grid requires about 30% fewer samples to represent the same amount of spatial information than an equivalent CC grid does, it is not widely used in practice. This is mainly because of the lack of efficient adaptation of high-quality volume reconstruction methods developed for the rectilinear volume representation.

In this paper we present a novel reconstruction technique for optimally sampled volume data. It is demonstrated that the proposed IEEE Visualization 2005 October 23-28, Minneapolis, MN, USA 0-7803-9462-3/05/$20.00 ©2005 IEEE. method well approximates the ideal low-pass filtering, and as a consequence, provides much higher image quality than previous methods do. Furthermore, our technique is significantly faster than the recently published cubic box-spline reconstruction proposed for the BCC grid [7].

In Section 2 previous work related to optimal regular volume sampling is reviewed. In Section 3 we introduce our new interpolation technique called Prefiltered Gaussian Reconstruction. In Section 4 this reconstruction scheme is adapted to the optimal BCC grid. The implementation results are reported in Section 5. Finally, in Section 6, the contribution of this paper is summarized.

div.head: PREVIOUS WORK
div.p: Many volume-processing and volume-rendering methods require the reconstruction of the underlying continuous function from the discrete samples stored in the volume data. The fidelity of the continuous reconstruction strongly depends on the quality of the applied resampling filter. Therefore several researchers analyzed different reconstruction and derivative filters, both in terms of accuracy and computational cost [16,13,17,18]. Generally, the wider the support of the filter in the spatial domain, the better its quality. Theoretically the best reconstruction filter is considered to be the sinc kernel, since it represents the ideal low-pass filter. In practice, however, it is difficult to convolve a signal with the sinc kernel, because of its infinite support. Therefore practical filters either approximate it or truncate it by an appropriate windowing function [13,24].

Convolution with a filter of wide support is rather expensive computationally if it is performed in the spatial domain. In the frequency domain, however, a convolution can be replaced by a simple multiplication. For frequent 2D and 3D resampling tasks, like rotation, warping, or upsampling, a variety of frequency-domain techniques have been proposed [11,4,6,28,30]. The reported results clearly demonstrated the superiority of frequency-domain resampling over spatial-domain methods in terms of image quality. Nevertheless, all these techniques were developed for rectilinear or CC grids, exploiting the separability of the discrete Fourier transform. The adaptation of these techniques to the BCC grid, however, is problematic because of its non-separability.

Isosurface-and volume-rendering algorithms which have been adapted to the BCC grid are based on spatial-domain interpolation. Theußl et al. used spherical extension of interpolation filters to render BCC-sampled data by the splatting method [26]. This approach, however, resulted in blurry images. Neophytou and Mueller [20] applied the splatting technique to efficiently render time-varying data sampled on a 4D BCC grid. Theußl et al. implemented also ray casting for the BCC grid [25] using various interpolation techniques, which produced ambivalent results. For example, directiondependent interpolation caused view-dependent artifacts. Similar problems arose when sheared trilinear interpolation was used for hardware-accelerated volume rendering of BCC-sampled data [15]. Isosurface construction methods adapted to the BCC grid [2,3] did not live up to the theoretical expectations either.

The breakthrough in this field was the derivation of linear and cubic box splines for the BCC grid by Entezari et al. [7]. The reported results demonstrated that the theoretical advantages of optimal sampling can really be exploited in practice. Nevertheless, the authors emphasize that the derived cubic box spline is an approximating filter, therefore further research is necessary to explore an exact interpolating filter, similar to the Catmull-Rom spline. Furthermore, the cubic box-spline reconstruction, as it was derived in [7], requires the evaluation of 81 terms for each neighboring voxel covered by the filter kernel. Therefore, without any simplification, it is impractical because of its enormous computational cost.

As the advantages of spatial-domain and frequency-domain re- sampling techniques are complementary, their combination seems to be straightforward. Therefore we decompose the reconstruction process into a frequency-domain discrete Gaussian deconvolution and a spatial-domain convolution with a truncated Gaussian kernel. In the following sections, it is shown that such a combined approach results in a good approximation of the ideal reconstruction. Furthermore, exploiting the periodicity and symmetry of the BCC grid, it can be applied to reconstruct optimally sampled data.

div.p: The 2D and 3D extensions of RBF reconstruction are usually used for scattered data interpolation, where the sample positions are assumed to be irregularly distributed in space [29,19,9]. Since in this case, apart from symmetry, no special properties of coefficient matrix A can be exploited, Equation 2 is typically solved by the general, but computationally expensive LU decomposition [29].

div.head: RBF reconstruction of a regularly sampled signal
div.p: Now assume that the sample positions are regularly located in space. In 1D it means that sample positions x i are evenly placed, thus extended ( f i = f i+N and w i = w i+N ) and it is interpolated at an arbitrary position x from the nearest N samples. In this case Equation 1 can be reformulated as a simple cyclic convolution:

As a consequence, the corresponding linear equation system (Equation 2) can be efficiently solved by a deconvolution in the frequency domain. Let us denote the discrete Fourier transforms of discrete functions f i , w i , and g i by F ω , W ω , and G ω respectively, where discrete function g i represents the sampled radial basis function as a convolution kernel:
In the frequency domain, convolution is performed as a multiplication:

The radial basis function φ (x) has to be carefully chosen since it has to be invertible. Otherwise the frequency-domain deconvolution is not possible because of a division by zero. Therefore we use an invertible Gaussian kernel as an RBF: φ (x) = e −x 2 /(2σ 2 ) . Note that, using the above reconstruction scheme, a continuous Gaussian reconstruction is performed after a discrete Gaussian deconvolution, which is actually a prefiltering of samples f i . Therefore we call this scheme Prefiltered Gaussian Reconstruction (PGR).

Prefiltering the samples in order to make an approximating filter interpolating is not new [1,27]. This conception was introduced by Blu et al. as Generalized Interpolation [1]. They proposed an efficient evaluation of the inverse Z-transform for non-interpolating filters of compact support. In contrast, we evaluate the inverse of a discrete Gaussian filter by using the FFT algorithm. As it will be demonstrated in the following discussion, the most important advantage of using a Gaussian kernel for prefiltered reconstruction is its scalability.

For a fixed N, which is the number of original samples, the impulse response of PGR is obtained asf (x) if f i = δ i . Figure 2 shows the impulse response for different values of σ and N = 16. According to our conjecture, by increasing parameter σ , the impulse response of PGR converges to the sincd(±1; N; x) kernel [31], which is defined as:
div.formula: sincd(±1; N; x) = [sincd(N − 1; N; x) + sincd(N + 1; N; x)]/2, (5)
div.p: where sincd(M; N; x) is the discrete analog of the sinc function:
div.formula: sincd(M; N; x) = sin( πMx T N ) Nsin( πx T N ) .(6)
div.p: Convolution with the sincd(±1; N; x) kernel is equivalent to a specific implementation of frequency-domain zero padding, where the spectral coefficient belonging to the index N/2 is halved and repeated twice [31]. Note that, zero padding is a global interpolation technique usually used for upsampling. In contrast, PGR can be used for local interpolation at an arbitrary sample position. In order to confirm our conjecture, we compared the discrete frequency response of PGR to that of zero padding. Figure 3 shows the Fourier transform of a discrete signal of resolution 1024 reconstructed from a discrete impulse function δ i of resolution 512 by using PGR with different settings of σ . As it is demonstrated, the higher the parameter σ , the closer the discrete frequency response of PGR to that of zero padding. Nevertheless, the exact mathematical proof of the convergence is still a subject of our future work.

PGR is similar to premultiplication, which was proposed by Malzbender [12] in order to approximate the ideal reconstruction kernel by a filter of compact support. Applying PGR, however, the reciprocal discrete Fourier coefficients of a Gaussian kernel are used for premultiplication, rather than the reciprocal discrete samples of a continuous Fourier transform.

div.head: Ringing (overshoot)
div.p: Although zero padding results in nearly ideal reconstruction, it might cause ringing artifacts (or overshoot) when it is applied for real-world data sampled under the Nyquist limit (see Figure 4a). Another alternative for sinc-like interpolation is a convolution with a windowed sinc kernel, which gradually cuts off in the frequency domain [24], and therefore reduces the ringing artifacts.

PGR naturally ensures a scalable gradual frequency cut-off. The smaller the parameter σ , the smaller the overshoot (Figure 4). On the other hand, by decreasing the value of σ , the smoothing effect of PGR is getting stronger (Figure 3). Therefore an appropriate setting of parameter σ is always a compromise.

div.head: ADAPTATION OF PGR TO THE BCC GRID
div.p: PGR can be easily adapted to volume data defined on a regular rectilinear grid by using the 3D extension of the Gaussian kernel. Furthermore, discrete deconvolution can be implemented in the frequency domain by performing 3D discrete Fourier transforms. However, the implementation of deconvolution for the nonseparable BCC grid is not as simple as for the separable regular rectilinear grid. Therefore PGR cannot be directly adapted to optimally sampled volume data. Nevertheless, the key idea of this paper is to exploit the periodicity and symmetry of the BCC grid in order to efficiently perform a discrete deconvolution in the frequency domain.

div.head: IMPLEMENTATION
div.p: PGR for the BCC grid was implemented using the highly optimized public-domain FFTW package [8]. From a practical point of view, the memory requirement of discrete prefiltering is an important aspect. Applying the following algorithm, only six 3D arrays of resolution N x × N y × N z have to be kept in the main memory (note that the initial data itself requires to store N x × N y × N z × 2 BCC samples):

div.p: Note that the prefiltering has to be performed only once, and afterwards an arbitrary sample can be evaluated by a simple Gaussian convolution according to Equation 7. For this operation only the prefiltered BCC samples (weighting factors w (1) i, j,k and w (2) i, j,k ) need to be stored in the main memory. Although the continuous Gaussian kernel has an infinite extent, it can be well approximated by a truncated Gaussian kernel in order to efficiently implement spatialdomain convolution. Because of this truncation PGR is theoretically an approximation. However, the approximation error vanishes exponentially if the number of neighboring voxels taken into account is increased. Therefore, from a practical point of view, PGR is an interpolation method. The influence of the truncated kernel is usually restricted to the interval [−3σ , 3σ ] 3 , since outside this interval the Gaussian function practically equals to zero. In our implementation we wanted to limit the convolution window to 4 × 4 × 4 × 2 voxels, therefore we used σ = 0.6.

First we tested our method on the classical Marschner-Lobb test signal (see Figure 1a), and compared it to the previous reconstruction techniques proposed for the BCC grid. Figure 6 shows images rendered by a high-quality ray caster using linear box-spline (a), cubic box-spline (b), and prefiltered Gaussian (c) reconstructions. The gradients for shading were estimated by central differencing on the reconstructed function. Alternatively the partial derivatives can also be obtained by convolving the discrete volume representation with the partial derivatives of the reconstruction kernel. Figure 7 shows the angular errors of the estimated gradients, where angular error of 30 degrees is mapped onto white. Note that linear boxspline reconstruction causes severe aliasing, while cubic box-spline reconstruction results in smoothing, and therefore slight displacement of the isosurface. In contrast, PGR (σ = 0.6) well preserves the depth of the wave valleys without significant aliasing.

In order to demonstrate the superiority of the BCC grid over the CC grid we implemented PGR for CC-sampled data as well. Figure 8 shows images rendered from 32 × 32 × 32 × 2 BCC samples (a) and approximately the same number (40 × 40 × 40) of CC samples (b). Since theoretically the BCC grid requires around 30% fewer samples to represent the same spectrum than an equivalent CC grid does, we also rendered images from 30% fewer (28 × 28 × 28 × 2) BCC samples (c) and from 30% more (45 × 45 × 45) CC samples (d). The corresponding angular errors are shown in Figure 9. As it was expected, due to the optimality of the BCC grid, the overall error levels (brightness) of images in Figure 9a and in Figure 9d are rather similar, while the overall brightness of the image in Figure 9b is comparable to that of the image in Figure 9c. The error of BCC reconstruction, however, seems more uniformly distributed than the error of CC reconstruction. This is probably because of that the BCC samples are more uniformly distributed in space than the CC samples [14].

PGR was tested also on practical data sets. As the BCC grid is a subgrid of the CC grid, we artificially produced BCC-sampled data by simply downsampling CC-sampled real-world data sets on a BCC subgrid. Nevertheless, in order to naturally generate BCCsampled data directly by a CT or MRI scanner, only the tomographic reconstruction software of such devices need to be modified. Since the slices are usually computed by the classical Filtered Back-Projection (FBP) algorithm [10], the discrete tomographic reconstruction can be easily performed on a translated 2D square grid for every second slice in order to provide BCC samples. However, until commercial BCC-sampling scanners are available, such a natural data acquisition on an optimal BCC grid is not possible. Figure 10 shows the reconstructions of our artificially produced BCC-sampled data sets. The resolution of the original MRI scan of a human brain was 256 × 256 × 166, while the resolution of the original CT scan of an engine block was 256 × 256 × 110. From these CC-sampled data sets we selected 128 × 128 × 83 × 2 and 128 × 128 × 55 × 2 BCC samples respectively. Note that, using linear box-spline reconstruction (a, b) aliasing appears as a regular pattern on the surfaces, while cubic box-spline reconstruction (c, d) blurs the high-frequency details. As it is clearly visible in Figure 10 (e, f), PGR does not smooth the surfaces, and preserves the fine details even better than linear box-spline reconstruction does.

Rendering times measured on a 3GHz Intel Pentium 4 PC with 1GB of RAM are shown in Table 1. Images of resolution 256 × 256 were generated by the same ray caster using different reconstruction techniques for resampling. Although PGR is slower than linear box-spline reconstruction, it is significantly faster than cubic boxspline reconstruction. Note that the time cost of the preprocessing for PGR, which is the discrete prefiltering, is relatively low compared to the rendering time. Nevertheless, the preprocessing has to be performed only once for each data set, and afterwards the preprocessed volume can be rendered from an arbitrary viewing direction.

div.head: CONCLUSION AND FUTURE WORK
div.p: In this paper a novel reconstruction scheme called Prefiltered Gaussian Reconstruction has been presented. It has been shown that it well approximates the ideal reconstruction, and can be adapted to volume data sampled either on a regular rectilinear grid or on an optimal BCC grid. Our method is robust and scalable, since the gradual cut-off in the frequency domain and the smoothing effect can be easily controlled by the parameter σ . It has been demonstrated that PGR provides much higher image quality than previous reconstruction methods proposed for optimally sampled data do. Furthermore PGR is an order of magnitude faster than the recently published cubic box-spline reconstruction technique adapted to the BCC grid. Therefore, we think that our work is an important step towards a wide-spread acceptance of optimal sampling in practical applications.

In our future work we plan to use the conventional graphics hardware to interactively render BCC-sampled volume data. Applying PGR, it can be exploited that image-aligned slices of a Gaussian reconstruction kernel are 2D Gaussian functions regardless of the viewing direction. Therefore the combination of PGR with slicebased hardware-accelerated rendering techniques, like the method proposed by Jang et al. [9], seems to be promising.
